wikipedia.name: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
wikipedia.description: In mathematics, the fundamental theorem of arithmetic, also called the unique factorization theorem and prime factorization theorem, states that every integer greater than 1 is prime or can be represented uniquely as a product of prime numbers, up to the order of the factors.[a][3][4][5] For example,

categories: Short description is different from Wikidata
Articles needing additional references from January 2024

relationships.target_theorem: Gauss proved the unique factorization theorem

relationships.source_theorem: Gauss's Disquisitiones Arithmeticae seems to be the first proof of the uniqueness part of the theorem

relationships.target_theorem: The fundamental theorem of arithmetic can also be proved without using Euclid's lemma
The first generalization of the theorem
It can also be proven that none of these factors obeys Euclid's lemma
Farisi compiled a paper in which he set out deliberately to prove the theorem
This forced him to an understanding of the first arithmetical functions and to a full preparation which led him to state for the first time the fundamental theorem

Overview
Integer factorization
Divisor
Unitary divisor
Divisor function
Prime factor
Fundamental theorem

wikipedia.name: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
wikipedia.description: The fundamental theorem of algebra, also called d'Alembert's theorem[1] or the d'Alembertâ€“Gauss theorem,[2] states that every non-constant single-variable polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root. This includes polynomials with real coefficients, since every real number is a complex number with its imaginary part equal to zero.

relationships.target_theorem:
Every polynomial has a real or complex root
Not to be confused with Fundamental theorem of arithmetic or Fundamental theorem
A first attempt at proving the theorem

relationships.source_theorem: The first textbook containing a proof of the theorem

relationships.target_theorem: Fred Richman proved a reformulated version of the theorem
There are several equivalent formulations of the theorem

relationships.source_theorem: Another algebraic proof of the fundamental theorem

relationships.target_theorem: There exists still another way to approach the fundamental theorem
Here are a few more consequences of the theorem

Properties of polynomial roots
While the fundamental theorem
A forgotten paper on the fundamental theorem
On the history of the fundamental theorem
A forgotten paper on the fundamental theorem

relationships.source_theorem: Gauss's second proof of the fundamental theorem

wikipedia.name: Fermat's Last Theorem
wikipedia.description: In number theory, Fermat's Last Theorem (sometimes called Fermat's conjecture, especially in older texts) states that no three positive integers a, b, and c satisfy the equation an + bn = cn for any integer value of n greater than 2. The cases n = 1 and n = 2 have been known since antiquity to have infinitely many solutions.[1]

relationships.target_theorem: Implied byEffective abc conjectureEffective modified Szpiro conjectureModularity theoremGeneralizationsBeal conjecture
The proposition was first stated as a theorem
Although other statements claimed by Fermat without proof were subsequently proven by others and credited as theorem
It is among the most notable theorem

relationships.source_theorem: Although he claimed to have a general proof of his conjecture

relationships.target_theorem: Ernst Kummer extended this and proved the theorem
Wiles succeeded in proving enough of the conjecture
Examining this elliptic curve with Ribet's theorem
Fermat's Last Theorem could also be used to contradict the modularity theorem
This is now known as the Pythagorean theorem
While Harvey Friedman's grand conjecture implies that any provable theorem
In the two centuries following its conjecture
Euler himself had proved the lemma
This had been the case with some other past conjecture

relationships.source_theorem: By accomplishing a partial proof of this conjecture

relationships.target_theorem: Gerhard Frey noted a link between Fermat's equation and the modularity theorem
This would conflict with the modularity theorem

Andrew Wiles and Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem
British mathematician Andrew Wiles

The now fully proved conjecture became known as the modularity theorem

An effective version of the abc conjecture
